image.altText: Smoke billows over Gaza buildings

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says the federal government is organising repatriation flights to help Australians stuck in Israel, as the war's death toll passes 2,000. Follow live.

title.children: Australia announces repatriation flights from Israel as death toll passes 2,000

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Gazan Ministry of Health says the death toll now stands at 950, with 5,000 other people injured. This is up from yesterday's estimate of 900 killed and 4,500 injured in Gaza.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Death toll in Gaza rises to 950

children.content: The Gazan Ministry of Health
says the death toll now stands at 950, with 5,000 other people injured.
This is up from yesterday's estimate of 900 killed and 4,500 injured in Gaza.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has announced the federal government will help Australians stuck in Israel after opening two repatriation flights leaving from Ben Gurion airport in Tel Aviv starting Friday. "For Australians who do not already have plans to leave through commercial options, Australian-government-assisted departure flights will depart from Friday. I want to thank Qantas for making their facility available," the prime minister said. Mr Albanese thanked Foreign Minister Penny Wong and Transport Minister Catherine King, who he said had helped "to organise these contingencies to make sure that we can get Australians who want to leave for home as soon as possible". Australians need to register for the flights with the Australian government's 24-hour Consular Emergency Centre which can be reached on +61 2 6261 3305 (from overseas) or 1300 555 135 (from within Australia).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM announces evacuation flights for Australians in Israel

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has announced the federal government will help Australians stuck in Israel after opening two repatriation flights leaving from Ben Gurion airport in Tel Aviv starting Friday.

Mr Albanese thanked Foreign Minister Penny Wong and Transport Minister Catherine King, who he said had helped "to organise these contingencies to make sure that we can get Australians who want to leave for home as soon as possible".
Australians need to register for the flights with the
Australian government's 24-hour Consular Emergency Centre which can be reached on +61 2 6261 3305 (from overseas) or 1300 555 135 (from within Australia).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The US is talking with Israel and Egypt about the idea of a safe passage for Gaza civilians as Israel air strikes target the enclave, national security adviser Jake Sullivan says. "We are focused on this question. There are consultations going on," Mr Sullivan told reporters at the White House on Tuesday. "But the details of that are something that are being discussed among the operational agencies and I don't want to share too much of that publicly at this time," Mr Sullivan said. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US, Israel and Egypt discussing safe passage corridor for Gaza civilians

children.content: The US is talking with Israel and Egypt about the idea of a safe passage for Gaza civilians as Israel air strikes target the enclave, national security adviser Jake Sullivan says.
"We are focused on this question. There are consultations going on," Mr Sullivan told reporters at the White House on Tuesday.
"But the details of that are something that are being discussed among the operational agencies and I don't want to share too much of that publicly at this time," Mr Sullivan said.

props.alt: A man wearing a suit and red tie and an American flag behind him looks down.

children.content: National security adviser Jake Sullivan during the daily press briefing at the White House.
(Reuters: Jonathan Ernst)
Reuters

title.children: 'There's nothing to be fearful about': Pat Dodson's Press Club message to undecided Voice voters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Isabella Higgins The prime minister has finished a highly symbolic campaign trip to Uluṟu. The majestic landscape is full of spirit and soul, a place where the strength and survival of an ancient culture is obvious, but this country also holds a significant spot in the current national referendum debate. It was here following a constitutional convention in 2017 that Indigenous leaders from around the country first called for an enshrined Indigenous Voice to Parliament to overcome enduring disempowerment and disadvantage. In this remote corner of the Northern Territory, the health, employment and educations gaps felt in Aboriginal communities are evident. Anthony Albanese met with some of the senior Aṉangu people who helped design the Uluṟu Statement from the Heart. With the Yes campaign lagging behind in the polls, the prime minister was trying to remind Australians in the final days of the referendum campaign — this is where the Voice to Parliament came from and this is who it is for.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why Anthony Albanese’s Uluru trip was important

children.content: Reporting by Isabella Higgins
The prime minister has finished a highly symbolic campaign trip to Uluṟu.

The majestic landscape is full of spirit and soul, a place where the strength and survival of an ancient culture is obvious, but this country also holds a significant spot in the current national referendum debate.

props.alt: Albanese speaks at a press conference with the red rock seen behind the group.

children.content: (ABC News: Isabella Higgins)

It was here following a constitutional convention in 2017 that Indigenous leaders from around the country first called for an enshrined Indigenous Voice to Parliament to overcome enduring disempowerment and disadvantage.
In this remote corner of the Northern Territory, the health, employment and educations gaps felt in Aboriginal communities are evident.
Anthony Albanese met with some of the senior Aṉangu people who helped design the Uluṟu Statement from the Heart.

With the Yes campaign lagging behind in the polls, the prime minister was trying to remind Australians in the final days of the referendum campaign — this is where the Voice to Parliament came from and this is who it is for.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As we head towards the Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum on October 14, many Australians are finding their views are at odds with those of their friends and family. You've probably heard someone tell you that it's best to avoid discussions about politics, but it's not always that simple, Relationships Australia NSW chief executive Elisabeth Shaw says. "We have seen families where there have been fallings-out over these issues, as we did with vaccination during the pandemic," Ms Shaw says. "These can be make-or-break issues, which might surprise a lot of people." A serious disagreement over politics or other important issues can cause long-term damage to relationships you may value. So, how should you approach these tricky conversations, especially if you know your views are different to those of your friends and family? You can continue reading this story by Declan Bowring for ABC Everyday by tapping the link below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How to manage disagreements about the Voice referendum with friends and family

featuredLink.title: 'Agree to disagree': How to manage tricky conversations about the Voice referendum - ABC Everyday

children.content: As we head towards the Indigenous Voice to Parliament
referendum on October 14, many Australians are finding their views are at odds with those of their friends and family.

props.alt: A generic photo of a man and a woman sitting on a couch with their backs to each other and their arms crossed.

children.content: (Adobe Stock)
You've probably heard someone tell you that it's best to avoid discussions about politics, but it's not always that simple, Relationships Australia NSW chief executive
Elisabeth Shaw
says.
"We have seen families where there have been fallings-out over these issues, as we did with vaccination during the pandemic," Ms Shaw says.
"These can be make-or-break issues, which might surprise a lot of people."
A serious disagreement over politics or other important issues can cause long-term damage to relationships you may value.
So, how should you approach these tricky conversations, especially if you know your views are different to those of your friends and family?
You can continue reading this story by
Declan Bowring
for ABC Everyday by tapping the link below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Matt Garrick The family of late Northern Territory land rights giant Yunupiŋu have voiced their sadness over comments made by Opposition Leader Peter Dutton yesterday, saying they "twisted" his legacy. The late Gumatj clan leader and former Australian of the Year passed away earlier this year at age 74. Mr Dutton was speaking at a press conference in Adelaide, where he made a link between Yunupiŋu's achievements in helping improve economic outcomes for his Yolŋu people, and how that was a reason Australia should vote against the "Canberra-based bureaucracy" of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice to Parliament. Indigenous Australians Minister Linda Burney called for Mr Dutton to apologise, accusing him of using the late leader's "name in vain" and of making inaccurate references to East Arnhem Land. Yunupiŋu's brother and now-leader of the Gumatj clan Djawa Yunupiŋu released a short statement in relation to Mr Dutton's comments, via the Yothu Yindi Foundation. "It saddens our family to see my brother's name and legacy twisted like this," Mr Yunupiŋu said. "He was a strong advocate for the Voice, and Mr Dutton knows that. "He heard the same message loud and clear when he met with the 13-clan leadership of the Dilak Council, who also support a Voice." Djawa Yunupiŋu and the Dilak Council offered their unequivocal support towards a Voice to Parliament at the Garma Festival in north-east Arnhem Land earlier this year. Mr Dutton has been approached for further comment. NOTE: Yunupiŋu's surname and image are used in accordance with the wishes of his family.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Family of Yunupiŋu 'saddened' by Peter Dutton's comments

children.content: Reporting by Matt Garrick
The family of late Northern Territory land rights giant
Yunupiŋu
have voiced their sadness over comments made by
Opposition Leader Peter Dutton
yesterday, saying they "twisted" his legacy.
The late Gumatj clan leader and former Australian of the Year passed away earlier this year at age 74.

Mr Dutton was speaking at a press conference in Adelaide, where he made a link between Yunupiŋu's achievements in helping improve economic outcomes for his Yolŋu people, and how that was a reason Australia should vote against the "Canberra-based bureaucracy" of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice to Parliament.
Indigenous Australians Minister Linda Burney
called for Mr Dutton to apologise, accusing him of using the late leader's "name in vain" and of making inaccurate references to East Arnhem Land.
Yunupiŋu's brother and now-leader of the Gumatj clan
Djawa Yunupiŋu
released a short statement in relation to Mr Dutton's comments, via the Yothu Yindi Foundation.

props.alt: Djawa sits in traditional clothing at the Garma festival.

children.content: Gumatj leader Djawa Yunupiŋu.
(Supplied)
"It saddens our family to see my brother's name and legacy twisted like this," Mr Yunupiŋu said.
"He was a strong advocate for the Voice, and Mr Dutton knows that.
"He heard the same message loud and clear when he met with the 13-clan leadership of the Dilak Council, who also support a Voice."
Djawa Yunupiŋu and the Dilak Council offered their unequivocal support towards a Voice to Parliament at the Garma Festival in north-east Arnhem Land earlier this year.
Mr Dutton has been approached for further comment.
NOTE: Yunupiŋu's surname and image are used in accordance with the wishes of his family.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Roos pick up the running and gunning Blue. North Melbourne trades picks 21 and 25 to Carlton for Zac Fisher and pick 17. Pretty good result for both parties, but my word. North Melbourne's draft hand is getting silly at this point.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: North Melbourne complete a trade for Zac Fisher

children.content: (Getty Images)
The Roos pick up the running and gunning Blue.
North Melbourne trades picks 21 and 25 to Carlton for Zac Fisher and pick 17.
Pretty good result for both parties, but my word. North Melbourne's draft hand is getting silly at this point.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Swans get both their men. Sydney have traded pick 33 to Collingwood for Taylor Adams. Grundy? Check. Adams? Check. Hamling and Jordon? Check and check. Future first-round pick from North? Why the hell not, check. The Swans have got their business done with a minimum of fuss.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Sydney complete trade for Taylor Adams

children.content: (Getty Images)
The Swans get both their men.
Sydney have traded pick 33 to Collingwood for Taylor Adams.
Grundy? Check. Adams? Check. Hamling and Jordon? Check and check. Future first-round pick from North? Why the hell not, check.
The Swans have got their business done with a minimum of fuss.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Another big domino has fallen. The Swans have got their man, and Brodie Grundy will be heading for the red and white. Sydney have traded pick 46 and a future second round pick to Melbourne for Brodie Grundy. Job done, and the Swans remain in a good position to ensure Taylor Adams follows soon after.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Sydney clinch Brodie Grundy deal

children.content: (Getty Images)
Another big domino has fallen. The Swans have got their man, and Brodie Grundy will be heading for the red and white.
Sydney have traded pick 46 and a future second round pick to Melbourne for Brodie Grundy.
Job done, and the Swans remain in a good position to ensure Taylor Adams follows soon after.
